DOC.HEADLINE: D.C. STOCKS: SLM, LOCKHEED MARTIN SHARES LEAD INDEX HIGHER

TEXT.P: Washington, D.C. stocks rose, led by the shares of SLM Holding Corp. and Lockheed Martin Corp.
The Bloomberg Washington Area stock index rose 1.91, or 1.31 percent, to 147.61. Of the 271 stocks in the price-weighted index, 160 rose, 45 were unchanged, and 66 fell.
So far this year the index has risen 29.9 percent. The index is designed to measure the Washington area economy by tracking the stock activity of its largest publicly traded companies.

SLM Holding is the Washington parent company of student loan reseller Sallie Mae. Its shares rose 4 1/8 to 144 1/2 on trading of 156,000 shares, below the three-month average daily volume of 202,691 shares, worth $22.5 million.

Today's rise followed a 12 percent decline last week by SLM's stock. Analysts attributed that drop mainly to concerns about pending congressional changes to regulations that govern what Sallie Mae can charge its borrowers.
Lockheed Martin rose 4 1/16 to 99 1/8 on trading of 1.2 million shares worth $116.3 million. Today's trading volume was twice the stock's average daily volume.

The aerospace company this morning said it's giving one of its computer hardware businesses, its airplane engine components business, and its share of the Globalstar satellite communications venture to General Electric Co. for the $2.8 billion of its preferred shares GE holds.
Lockheed Martin said it expects a $300 million gain from the transaction. GE will record a $1.3 billion gain.
America Online Inc., the Dulles, Virginia-based online service provider, rose 2 3/4 to 79 3/4 on trading of 1.5 million shares worth $124 million. Its average daily volume is 1.4 million shares.
That rise followed a decline of 10 3/16 last week. It also came three days before America Online releases its first-quarter earnings report.
According to an IBES International Inc. survey of 12 analysts, the company is expected to earn 12 cents a share for the quarter. In the year-ago quarter, it had profit of 17 cents a share.

On a percentage basis, the Washington Area index lagged the Dow Jones Industrial Average, which rose 232.32, or 3.12 percent, to 7674.40, the Standard & Poor's 500, which rose 24.37, or 2.66 percent, to 938.99, and the Nasdaq Combined Composite, which rose 36.37, or 2.28 percent, to 1629.98.
